mentions.title: Rounding Up Some Recent Copyright Decisions
mentions.content: Rounding Up Some Recent Copyright Decisions - Technology & Marketing Law Blog Technology & Marketing Law Blog Menu Biography Academic Materials Writing Presentations Resources Courses Advertising & Marketing Law Contract Law Copyright Law Internet Law IP Survey Legal Ethics Contact Blogs Tertium Quid Blog Eric Goldman’s Personal Blog About the Blogger Browse: Home » 2025 » April » Rounding Up Some Recent Copyright Decisions Rounding Up Some Recent Copyright Decisions April 12, 2025 · by Eric Goldman · in Copyright , Derivative Liability , E-Commerce , Trademark A few recent copyright cases worthy of blog coverage, but not worthy of a standalone post. Omnia Studios Ltd. v. JD E-Commerce America Ltd., 2025 WL 961473 (W.D.N.Y. March 31, 2025) This case involves the service Joybuy, which listed items for sale in Walmart.com’s marketplace. The plaintiff alleges that Joybuy sold counterfeit items, as confirmed by test buys. The court is unclear about how Joybuy operates, but it appears that Joybuy (via the entity “JD”) runs its own online marketplace. As a result, the Joybuy listings on Walmart.com are actually third-party merchant listings with Joybuy syndicated to Walmart. This ruling deals with the 512(c) defense. The plaintiff argued that Joybuy/JD did not qualify as a “service provider” because it was the direct merchant. This is a rare attack on the capacious definition of a service provider, and it did not succeed. The court says that Joybuy sufficiently established that it ran its own online marketplace and thus qualified as a service provider. Shockingly, the plaintiff didn’t contest any of the other 512 elements, so Joybuy defeats the lawsuit. The plaintiff argued that Walmart received direct financial benefits from the listings, so it is disqualified from the 512(c) defense. Rather than address that argument, the court does a switcheroo and says that Walmart doesn’t have the right and ability to control the infringements. This switcheroo doesn’t answer the question on the table, because the 512(c) defense requires the defendant to BOTH not have the requisite supervisory ability AND not have a direct financial interest in the infringements. Showing that Walmart satisfied one 512(c) defense element doesn’t have any bearing on a different defense element. Still ignoring the question on the table, the court explains why Walmart lacked the requisite supervisory ability: Wal-Mart exercised little influence over the activities of its users. As the operator of the marketplace, Wal-Mart allowed users to take the lead on creating listings and thereby selling products—including infringing ones. Wal-Mart’s ability to remove infringing content does not grant it the right and ability to control, nor does its role in screening content as it was listed. The plaintiff also argued that Walmart had red flags of infringement because it was willfully blind. The court says that even if that’s true, Walmart expeditiously removed the infringing items, typically “within a day of receiving the complaint.” The court gives Walmart some grace over the exceptions: Plaintiffs point to only a small number of listings that remained active for longer periods of time, but this seems to speak more to the technical difficulties involved in curating an online marketplace than a sign of willful blindness. As reported by Snukset, these lapses are attributable to glitches within Wal-Mart’s automated takedown system—Plaintiffs have not submitted evidence that satisfactorily disputes this. The plaintiffs also challenged Walmart’s implementation of its repeat infringer policy because it didn’t terminate JD. The court accepts Walmart’s explanation: Snukset explains at length why Wal-Mart did not terminate JD or its marketplaces from Walmart.com: because Wal-Mart knew that JD was “not the actual source” of the infringing products and did not create the listings themselves, that JD had a relatively low number of infringement complaints relative to market volume, and a “lack of evidence of prior notice of Plaintiff’s IP rights.” All of these constitute appropriate reasons why an ISP would refrain from terminating a user. Another act of grace from the court. Having a low number of infringement complaints still would sound like a recidivist to most courts. All told, Walmart gets summary judgment on the DMCA online safe harbor defense. I can’t tell why the plaintiff’s narrative fell so flat before this judge, but I don’t know how repeatable this ruling is. The contributory trademark infringement claim against Walmart goes the same. “The evidence shows that Defendants were on-notice that their marketplaces contained infringing listings—Plaintiff and their agents issued infringement complaints on dozens of such listings. In response to these complaints, however, the evidence shows that Defendants promptly took down nearly all of the infringing listings.” As Miracle Max would say, “There’s a big difference between mostly removed and all removed,” but this court treats them as equivalent. In a footnote, the court says: “Wal-Mart points out that Plaintiffs assert “relatively small levels of infringing sales—Chinn ($311.40), Collis ($2,195.28), Omnia ($170.01) and Turkey ($153.66).” Plaintiffs dispute whether these constitute “relatively small levels.”” Say what? This case involved less than $3k of total gross sales??? That seems like dubious grounds to go after a giant business like Walmart. After II Movie, LLC v. WideOpenWest Finance LLC, No. 1:21-cv-01901-DDD-CYC (D. Colo. March 14, 2025) This is a lawsuit against an IAP for subscriber-caused copyright infringement. The contributory copyright infringement claim survives a motion to dismiss when the plaintiffs allege “that WideOpenWest was notified of over 33,750 specific instances of direct infringement at over 13,000 of its IP addresses, including approximately 100 instances of specific infringements at several IP addresses, yet it did not investigate further or take any action to stop continued infringement by the subscriber accounts associated with those IP addresses.” The IAP argued that Taamneh changed contributory copyright infringement, but that argument was rejected in UMG v. Grande (see also In re Frontier ). With respect to the vicarious copyright infringement claim, the court credits the following allegations: at least one subscriber continued using WideOpenWest’s internet service because WideOpenWest is “amazing on torrents” and the subscriber had “never gotten a letter or notice” despite having “downloaded truly an outrageous amount of data.” That subscriber recommended WideOpenWest to someone else looking for an internet service provider that is “‘less’ strict on downloading.” (Note that nothing in that subscriber’s testimonial refers to copyright infringement. The subscriber could have been celebrating their massive bandwidth consumption, not their massive infringement spree). As a result, the court accepted the inference that “copyright infringement was a draw for WideOpenWest’s customers, and that WideOpenWest reaped some financial benefit, via attraction or retention of accounts, directly from its users’ downloading and distribution of the plaintiffs’ copyrighted works.” As I’ve mentioned many times before, treating IAPs as the deputy copyright sherriffs is bad news for the Internet. For more, see the linkwrap below. Maddry v. Luoxue, 2025 WL 822692 (N.D. Cal. March 14, 2025) The copyrighted work at issue in this case is a card game called “Discernment,” which contains a deck of “made up of cards with biblical or funny Christian phrases” that are garbled and need to be decoded. The copyright owner allgedly got flooded with Chinese knockoffs in online marketplaces that undercut his price. He complained to Amazon, which temporarily suspended the listings. Amazon said the listings would be restored unless he sued the knockoff merchants. He sued the online marketplaces pro se and sought an ex parte TRO for various remedies. His requests are all denied. The court says that it cannot bind the online marketplaces because they aren’t defendants and thus are not reachable via FRCP 65. This goes straight to the heart of the SAD Scheme, where rightsowners keep getting TROs that purport to bind the online marketplaces–seemingly lawlessly. The court says that 512(c)(3) takedown notices are supposed to provide the quick relief he seeks, and the court can’t tell if he has availed himself of that procedure. This is a bit unfair to the plaintiff. 512(c)(3) is a way of disqualifying a defendant from the DMCA online safe harbor, but it’s not mandatory that copyright owners send takedown notices to succeed in court. However, as a practical matter, courts have been skeptical when copyright owners sue intermediaries without trying 512(c)(3) notices first, and that appears to be the case again here. The court also says the plaintiff can discover the identity of the merchants through 512(h) subpoenas, so an ex parte TRO is unnecessary. That’s true, but what about disclosures mandated in the INFORM Consumers Act? The court denies the plaintiff’s request to enjoin the merchants from making listings because the complaint doesn’t provide evidence of copyright registrations. An always-embarrassing mistake, even for a copyright owner proceeding pro se. Lopez v. Meta Platforms, Inc., 2025 WL 965811 (S.D.N.Y. March 31, 2025) Lopez claims copyright and trademark ownership of the “NYC New York Cannabis” logo: Lopez claims Meta and its users used the logo to promote the “NYC Canna Cruise.” The problem is that Lopez doesn’t have a copyright registration in the logo because the Copyright Office refused it under its standard policy against registering logos. The unjust enrichment claim fails because it’s preempted by the Copyright Act. The court doesn’t give Lopez another chance to amend in part because “Lopez is a serial IP litigant who has filed at least 41 lawsuits in this District against more than 100 different defendants.” Selected Posts About IAP Copyright Liability Internet Access Providers Face Contributory Copyright Liability for Subscribers’ Infringements–UMG v. Grande The Supreme Court Didn’t Change Secondary Copyright Liability Standards in the Taamneh Ruling—In re Frontier Internet Access Providers Can Be Contributorily Liable for Subscribers’ Infringements–Sony Music v. Cox Another Rough Copyright Ruling for Internet Access Providers–Bodyguard v. RCN Copyright Plaintiffs Can’t Figure Out What Copyrights They Own, Court Says ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ IAP Defeats Vicarious Copyright Infringement Claim–UMG v. Bright House Data Center Avoids Copyright Liability By Forwarding DMCA Notices to Its Customer–ALS Scan v. Steadfast Another Terrible Copyright Ruling on IAPs’ Liability for Users’ File-Sharing–Warner v. Charter Internet Access Provider Gets Another Devastating Result in a Secondary Copyright Infringement Case—Sony v. Cox Internet Access Provider May Be Vicariously Liable for Subscribers’ BitTorrent Downloads–Warner Bros. v. Charter Are Internet Access Providers Liable for Their Subscribers’ Copyright Infringements?–UMG v. Grande Before Graduated Response, There Was BSA’s “Define the Line” Program. What Happened to It? (Guest Blog Post) The “Graduated Response” Deal: What if Users Had Been At the Table? (Co-Authored Post) Share this: Email Print Facebook LinkedIn Twitter Tumblr Pinterest Pocket Reddit Comments and Pings ← SAD Scheme-Style Case Falls Apart When the Defendant Appears in Court—King Spider v. mentions.title: Whispeara Under Review: Best Natural Hearing Support Formula on the Market
mentions.content: Whispeara Under Review: Best Natural Hearing Support Accessibility: Skip TopNav Whispeara Under Review: Best Natural Hearing Support Formula on the Market Discover the Natural Formula Backed by Science That Helps Restore Hearing Clarity, Reduce Tinnitus, and Support Long-Term Ear-Brain Health Without Devices or Drugs. April 12, 2025 14:11 ET | Source: Whispeara Whispeara New York City, April 12, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Hearing loss isn’t just an age-related condition—it’s a growing global concern affecting people of all backgrounds and lifestyles. Whether it’s the constant exposure to environmental noise, the long-term effects of earbud usage, or the slow, creeping impact of aging, millions are silently suffering. From asking people to repeat themselves to missing key parts of conversations, the frustration adds up. And for many, the problem isn't just hearing—it’s the emotional toll that comes with it. But there's hope. Whispeara can bring relief and restore the joy of sound. As social situations become more difficult and the feeling of isolation sets in, mental health can begin to deteriorate. Anxiety, fatigue, and even depression can follow when auditory clarity disappears. And while modern solutions like hearing aids promise quick relief, they often fall short of expectations. These devices can amplify sound indiscriminately, fail to address the root cause of the problem, and often come with a hefty price tag. Surgeries and prescription medications present another set of challenges, including high costs, risks, and side effects. That’s why many people are turning to natural solutions—remedies designed to support hearing from the inside out. But the wellness space is crowded, and not all supplements are created equal. Enter Whispeara , a powerful hearing support formula crafted with natural ingredients to help users experience sharper sound, reduced ringing in the ears, and stronger connections between the brain and auditory system. Whispeara stands out because it’s designed to do more than mask symptoms. Its ingredients are strategically chosen to support overall ear health, nourish the auditory nerves, and help fight the inflammation and oxidative stress that contribute to hearing loss. With a growing number of satisfied users, glowing testimonials, and rising popularity, Whispeara is quickly being recognized as one of the best natural alternatives to traditional hearing solutions. Its effectiveness is undeniable, and it's time for you to experience it. In this in-depth review, we’ll explore why hearing loss is becoming so common, what makes Whispeara so effective, how it works inside the body, what real users are saying, and how it compares to similar products on the market. By the end of this article, you’ll have all the information you need to decide whether Whispeara is the right choice to restore clarity, confidence, and quality of life. Why You’re Struggling to Hear – Understanding the Root Causes Before delving into the functionality of Whispeara, it’s crucial to grasp the intricate nature of hearing loss and tinnitus. These are not simple mechanical issues of 'old ears,' as commonly perceived. The causes are multifaceted, ranging from neurological interference to cellular inflammation. Your ears often bear the brunt of a breakdown in communication between your brain, nerves, and auditory pathways. The Brain-Ear Disconnect One of the most overlooked causes of hearing problems is a breakdown in the brain’s ability to interpret sound signals. Sound isn’t just heard through the ears—it’s processed and understood in the brain. The brain plays a crucial role in not just receiving sound signals, but also in interpreting and making sense of them. Over time, due to aging, oxidative damage, or toxin exposure, this processing system can become sluggish or distorted. This is why many people with age-related hearing loss say they can hear sounds, but can’t understand them. It’s not a problem with loudness—it’s a problem with clarity. Whispeara plays a pivotal role in addressing this critical disconnect. It supports the neurological pathways that carry sound signals from the ear to the brain. By enhancing nerve communication, it has the potential to restore sharper interpretation of sound and improve speech comprehension in noisy environments. This offers hope for those struggling with hearing issues. Oxidative Stress and Inflammation Every day, your ears are exposed to oxidative stress caused by free radicals—unstable molecules that damage cells over time. This damage affects the tiny hair cells inside your cochlea that are responsible for detecting sound vibrations. Once these cells are destroyed, they don’t regenerate, making prevention and protection critical. In addition, chronic inflammation in the auditory system can reduce blood flow to the inner ear, choke off nerve endings, and hinder the repair of damaged tissues. Together, oxidative stress and inflammation form the silent villains behind progressive hearing loss. Many of the ingredients in Whispeara are rich in antioxidants and natural anti-inflammatory agents. These work to neutralize free radicals and support circulation to the inner ear, creating a more hospitable environment for sound transmission and nerve health. Environmental and Lifestyle Factors Daily habits can also accelerate hearing decline. Loud environments, constant earbud use, poor nutrition, smoking, unmanaged stress, and even dehydration can all compromise ear health. These factors can lead to oxidative stress, inflammation, and damage to the auditory system. Add in factors like earwax buildup, past infections, or exposure to toxins, and it becomes clear that hearing loss is rarely due to a single issue—it’s usually the result of a cascade of damaging influences. What’s worse, the onset is often so gradual that many people don’t realize how much they’ve lost until it’s too late. Conversations become harder to follow, high-pitched sounds vanish, and that faint ringing or buzzing sound—tinnitus—starts to become more frequent and persistent. Whispeara was meticulously developed with all these contributing factors in mind. Its comprehensive formula is designed to support the full auditory ecosystem. From cellular repair and nerve protection to circulatory enhancement and brain connectivity, Whispeara is a holistic solution that instills confidence in both prevention and recovery from hearing issues. Don’t Wait—Grab Whispeara Now for Natural Hearing Support What is Whispeara? A Full Breakdown of the Formula and Its Origins Whispeara isn’t just another generic supplement on the market—it’s a precision-formulated natural hearing support formula designed to help restore auditory clarity, reduce tinnitus, and protect long-term ear and brain health. But what exactly is it? And how did it come to stand out in a sea of overpromising products? Let’s dive into the origin of Whispeara, what makes it unique, and why it’s becoming the top choice for people seeking a natural path to sharper hearing. A Solution Born From Frustration According to Whispeara’s official page, the formula was developed in response to a growing problem: millions of individuals suffering from progressive hearing loss, ringing in the ears, and deep frustration with conventional solutions like hearing aids, medications, or surgeries. The creators behind Whispeara recognized that many of the available options on the market failed to address the root causes of auditory decline. Hearing aids merely amplify sound—they don’t repair or protect. Prescription medications often treat symptoms with a laundry list of side effects. And surgical options, while occasionally effective, are both expensive and invasive. Whispeara, in contrast, was formulated to be simple, non-invasive, and accessible to everyone. It was built on the philosophy that restoring hearing requires supporting the full system—ear, brain, and nerve health—not just amplifying external sounds. This approach is designed to provide relief and comfort to those struggling with hearing issues. A Comprehensive, Multi-Stage Approach Whispeara’s standout feature lies in its multi-layered formula. Rather than focusing on just one element of ear health, the supplement takes a holistic view, providing a comprehensive solution that addresses various aspects of hearing health. This is designed to reassure the audience of the thoroughness of the product. Detoxification : Helps cleanse the auditory system from toxins and oxidative stressors that disrupt inner ear and brain communication. Repair and Nourishment : Delivers essential nutrients to rebuild and support the delicate structures of the ear and auditory nerves. Neural Activation : Enhances brain-ear communication by supporting cognitive clarity and neurotransmitter function involved in processing sound. Inflammation Defense : Includes anti-inflammatory agents to reduce swelling and increase circulation in the auditory system. This full-spectrum support is what separates Whispeara from many single-function hearing formulas that may only target tinnitus or ear circulation. Why Whispeara is Gaining Momentum As more people search for effective, affordable, and natural ways to manage their hearing challenges, Whispeara has quickly become one of the most trusted options available. Its rise in popularity isn’t just due to smart marketing—it’s because the product offers a comprehensive alternative to the limitations of traditional hearing interventions. In fact, the product is often referred to as the best natural hearing support formula available in 2025, thanks to its carefully researched blend of ingredients, its non-habit-forming design, and its commitment to long-term hearing wellness. From individuals in their 40s starting to experience early signs of hearing decline, to seniors who are tired of relying on clunky, uncomfortable hearing devices, Whispeara is proving to be a welcome, empowering solution. And as we’ll see in the next section, the formula behind it is more than just impressive—it’s rooted in science. Order Whispeara Today and Start Hearing the World Clearly Again Inside the Formula – Ingredient Deep Dive At the heart of Whispeara’s success is its carefully chosen blend of natural ingredients, each selected for its unique contribution to auditory health, neurological function, and cellular protection. This isn’t a random cocktail of herbs—it’s a purpose-built formula designed to address hearing loss and tinnitus at the source. This emphasis on purposeful design is intended to instill confidence in the effectiveness of our product. Let’s explore the core ingredients inside Whispeara and the science behind how each one contributes to better hearing, reduced ringing, and long-term ear-brain harmony. The Science of Hearing Support Compounds Unlike standard hearing supplements that rely on just a few generic ingredients, Whispeara combines over a dozen nutrients, antioxidants, and plant extracts. These ingredients work synergistically to protect the auditory nerves, improve blood flow to the inner ear, and reduce inflammation that interferes with sound processing. Key components include: Moomiyo: The Unique Adaptogen for Cellular Vitality Research by Shakirov (2021), Ivanov (2020), and Kolesnikov (2019) has shown that Moomiyo (also known as Shilajit) plays a powerful role as a natural adaptogen with multi-system support capabilities. It enhances immune function, modulates inflammatory responses, and increases physical resilience—all of which are crucial for the maintenance of cochlear health and inner ear function. Within Whispeara, Moomiyo stands out as a foundational antioxidant, uniquely contributing to the detoxification of the auditory system, support for ear canal detox, and reduction of cumulative stress that leads to age-related hearing decline. As a keystone botanical, Moomiyo's deep cellular restoration potential elevates Whispeara above the status quo of ear health supplements. Alpha-GPC: The Cognitive Enhancer for Brain-Ear Synchronization Studies by Kato et al. (2021), Canal et al. (1991), Gatti et al. (2011), and Parker et al. (2015) underscore the impact of Alpha-Glycerylphosphorylcholine (Alpha-GPC) on neurotransmitter support, cognitive clarity, and neuroplasticity. In Whispeara, Alpha-GPC plays a crucial role in the restoration of hearing clarity by optimizing acetylcholine transmission, a key neurotransmitter in the auditory cortex. This nutrient supports both the processing speed of auditory signals and mood regulation, helping to address the mental fog and frustration often linked with tinnitus and hearing loss. Sangiorgi et al. (1994) even noted its promise in managing cognitive decline, placing Whispeara in a class of neuro-hearing protection formulas rather than just a basic supplement. GABA: The Neural Soother for Tinnitus and Auditory Overload Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid (GABA), supported by Smith et al. (2018) and Lee et al. (2017), is the brain’s primary inhibitory neurotransmitter, essential for calming hyperactive nerve signals. In cases of tinnitus and auditory fatigue, dysregulated excitatory activity is common. Whispeara's use of GABA is instrumental in soothing overactive auditory pathways, promoting tranquility in the brain’s hearing centers. This mechanism is a key component of Whispeara’s tinnitus formula, helping to reduce ringing, buzzing, and static noise—a benefit often echoed in real reviews of Whispeara. Mucuna Pruriens (L-Dopa): Neuromotor and Auditory Enhancement Gupta et al. (2019) and Zhang et al. (2020) highlight L-Dopa extracted from Mucuna Pruriens as a dopaminergic precursor vital for neuroregeneration and motor response. In hearing, dopamine helps modulate synaptic strength in auditory nerve fibers, particularly those that relay sound intensity and pitch. By including L-Dopa, Whispeara reinforces the brain-ear connection, improves response to environmental sound stimuli, and supports neurotransmitter balance. This compound is especially important in addressing age-related hearing decline and supplements that improve auditory signals. L-Arginine: The Vascular Booster for Inner Ear Circulation According to Wu et al. (2016) and Bescos et al. (2012), L-Arginine is a nitric oxide precursor that enhances vascular dilation, thereby improving blood flow to inner ear structures. Good circulation is essential for delivering nutrients and oxygen to the cochlea and surrounding tissues. Whispeara’s use of L-Arginine supports inner ear function, enhances auditory clarity, and contributes to ear health supplements that work by facilitating microvascular repair and nutrient transport—elements that are crucial in hearing improvement through supplements. L-Tyrosine: Resilience Under Cognitive Load L-Tyrosine, as studied by Deijen et al. (2000) and Neri et al. (2015), is a precursor to dopamine and norepinephrine, making it vital for stress resilience and focus under pressure. For individuals with hearing challenges, especially in loud or chaotic environments, the brain’s ability to focus and filter sound is often impaired. By incorporating L-Tyrosine, Whispeara enhances auditory concentration, combats cognitive fatigue, and supports neuro-auditory pathways—making it a key player in the formula’s ability to restore hearing naturally and promote hearing clarity support. Detox, Repair, and Restore Each capsule of Whispeara is designed to perform three key functions, ensuring comprehensive auditory health: Detoxify the auditory system – clearing buildup and neutralizing toxins that interfere with hearing. Rebuild and nourish – supporting healthy ear tissue, hair cells, and nerves. Improve neural connections – enhancing the way your brain interprets sound signals sent from the ear. This is especially important for individuals experiencing high-pitched ringing, buzzing, or static-like noise in the ears. Tinnitus often stems from miscommunication between damaged nerves and the auditory cortex. Whispeara's formula helps soothe this interference by calming inflammation and re-establishing clear nerve pathways. All-Natural, Non-Habit-Forming, and Easy to Use Whispeara stands out from other supplements in its category. It’s not a synthetic compound or a pharmaceutical-grade chemical. Instead, it's a gentle, non-habit-forming, and all-natural solution for auditory health. Every ingredient is included in clinically supported dosages and manufactured in a facility that follows strict quality control practices. Whispeara is not just safe, but also inclusive. It’s vegetarian-friendly, gluten-free, and free from GMOs or artificial additives—making it a safe choice for most individuals looking for an all-natural path to restored hearing. This emphasis on inclusivity is designed to make our potential customers feel catered to and considered in our product design. Say Goodbye to Ringing—Buy Whispeara While Supplies Last How Whispeara Works in the Body Hearing is more than just what your ears pick up—it’s what your brain understands. Whispeara was uniquely formulated not just to enhance the ears, but to restore the entire hearing system, including the neurological connections that interpret sound. This innovative, multi-step internal approach is what sets Whispeara apart from temporary fixes like hearing aids or masking devices, and it's sure to pique your interest. Rather than amplifying noise, Whispeara helps the body work better—clearing pathways, reducing inflammation, and optimizing the transmission of sound from the ears to the brain.Here’s how the process unfolds. The 3-Stage Process of Hearing Restoration Whispeara follows a phased biological process that mirrors the body’s own repair mechanisms. Its ingredients work in unison through the following stages, providing a natural and reassuring path to hearing restoration: Stage 1: Detoxification and Ear Cleansing Whispeara begins by targeting the toxic buildup that often blocks optimal auditory function. Environmental pollutants, heavy metals, synthetic chemicals, and even chronic stress can introduce toxins into the bloodstream. These can interfere with nerve signaling and cause inflammation in the inner ear. Whispeara’s antioxidant-rich ingredients like green tea extract and hawthorn berry go to work clearing this cellular debris, reducing oxidative stress, and refreshing the delicate tissues responsible for sound detection. Stage 2: Repair and Nutritional Rebuilding Once the environment is cleared, the next phase focuses on strengthening the physical structures involved in hearing. This includes the cochlea, auditory nerves, and neuro-auditory pathways. mentions.title: Epomaker Magforce 68 Keyboard Review: Simplicity, Compactness, & Performance In One Package
mentions.content: Epomaker Magforce 68 Keyboard Review: Simplicity, Compactness, & Performance In One Package Hardware 8.5 Epomaker Magforce 68 Keyboard Review: Simplicity, Compactness, & Performance In One Package Muhammad Zuhair • Apr 12, 2025 at 02:08 PM EDT • Copy Shortlink Epomaker Magforce 68 Price $159.99 There's no doubt in the fact that Epomaker is a leading keyboard manufacturer, offering one of the best product lineups, ranging from full-sized keyboards, all the way to 65% designs, and they manage to nail every single one of them. Now, with Epomaker's Magforce 68, the company has been able to integrate compactness, design, and quality all in a single package, and this particular keyboard is what I would call one of the best options out there if you are looking for something "small." Epomaker Magforce 68 - Gateron Magnetic Jade Pro Switches, Hall Effect Technology & Speedy Type-C Connection Well, in the keyboards segment, there are really many 65% layout options that are said to be something a hardcore gamer would prefer, and Epomaker probably had these in mine before designing the Magforce 68. For someone like me whose work performance revolves around having a decent keyboard, my experience with this keyboard has been a charm. While the "compactness" hasn't appealed to me much, the typing quality is simply something that I am sure every purchaser will appreciate. Related Story Wedbush’s Dan Ives Thinks Trump Has Taken “The Doomsday Scenario Off The Table” And Tech Stocks Will Rally Come Monday, But One Options Market Veteran Feels “It’s A Crowded Trade” For a quick rundown of Epomaker Magforce 68 specifications, it features the Gateron Magnetic Jade Pro switches, which we'll discuss extensively ahead of time, along with a CNC aluminum body and much more. Here's a summary of the keyboard's features/specifications: Specification Details Brand EPOMAKER Model Magforce 68 Layout 65% ANSI US Layout Number of Keys 68 keys Connectivity Type-C Wired Compatibility WIN Case Material Aluminum Finish Anodized Flex-Cut No Flex-Cut Mounting Structure Top-Mount Plate Material FR4 PCB Thickness 1.6mm Stabilizers Plate-Mount Stabilizer Typing Angle 7 degree Sound Dampening Poron Sandwich Foam, Bottom Foam, Bottom EVA Keycaps Profile Cherry Profile Keycaps Material PBT Plastic Keycaps Manufacturing Technique Double-Shot RGB South-facing, per-key RGB Polling Rate 8000Hz Scan Rate 32kHz per key Latency 0.125ms (USB) Anti-Ghosting N-Key Rollover Keyboard Dimensions 314.5 * 113.9 * 38.6 mm Keyboard Weight 1.5kg Package Weight About 2kg Epomaker Magforce 68 - Unboxing & Close-Up The packaging of the keyboard is undoubtedly creative, as the box features a black and blue-themed design, with the branding at the very front. When you open up the box, there's cushioning on both the top and the bottom, which means that the company has ensured that the unit doesn't get damaged when shipping it across different regions. Inside the box, you get the standard manual, a Type-C USB cable, and a keycap puller, which is pretty standard for every keyboard. You also get extra Gateron Magnetic Jade Pro switches in case a replacement is needed, which might come in handy. When I saw the keyboard for the first time, I started to think about the unit's compactness, since I could almost carry its weight entirely at the palm of my hands. That is indeed the beauty of a 65% layout, since not only does it make portability much easier, but it occupies a little space on your desk, which means that you can use the extra space left for something else. But, you do get void of elements such as a dedicated numpad, so it is more of a consumer choice in the end. Starting with the keycaps come in a cherry profile design, which is the common notion in the segment. They are made out of PBT Plastic, which not only is a sturdy material but also ensures that there are no thumbprint impressions on the keycaps after extensive use, and I did notice this after using the keyboard for several days. Another interesting factor about the Magforce 68 is its sound-dampening mechanism, which uses Poron Sandwich Foam as the main cushion, creating that "crisp" typing sound. Epomaker Magforce 68 - Design Language, Hall Effect Technology & Gateron Magnetic Switches One thing about the keyboard that makes it a bit weird is the design language. The overall vibe of the product is seen as something "minimalistic" and more professional-oriented, but switching on the RGB makes the design layout complicated. Apart from this, the RGB really strikes out when you look at it for the very first time, and a more "diffused" look would have been a better choice, like the Galaxy100 counterpart. One of the standout features of the Magforce 68 is the "Hall Effect" technology, which uses a magnetic field to detect keystrokes, providing a smoother and quieter experience. Here's how Epomaker describes it: This feature allows users to fine-tune the actuation distance, catering to specific gaming or typing preferences. The Snap Tap function ensures rapid keystroke registration, while the Dead Zone adjustment eliminates unintended inputs, providing unparalleled control. This level of customization, powered by magnetic switches, ensures that every keystroke is accurate and consistent, enhancing performance across various use cases. So, consumers of different segments could easily fine-tune the actuation distance to get the desired typing experience, which really opens up the Magforce 68 to several types of users. You can utilize Epomaker's cloud adjustment platform to fine-tune the keyboard's performance. Speaking of the onboard switches, the Epomaker Magforce 68 comes with the widely-known Gateron Magnetic Jade Pro, a magnetic linear switch popular for their "cracky" sound, similar to Mahjong tiles clicking together. They come with a travel distance of 3.5mm with a lifespan of over 100 million keystrokes. These switches are primarily used in keyboards supporting the Hall Effect technology and are widely used by a variety of keyboard integrators. Since switches are a personal preference, I won't comment much on them, apart from the fact that if you don't like a "cracky-sounded" keyboard, the Magforce 68 isn't for you. Epomaker Magforce 68 Conclusion - Ideal Option If Compact & High-Performing Keyboard Is Your Need This particular keyboard is one of the best options in a 65% layout segment, but it comes with a hefty price tag of $159.99, which might seem justified if you look at the specifications alone. If you are eager to purchase the Epomaker Magforce 68, you can refer to the company's official website here and enjoy a great experience. 8.5 WCCFTECH RATING The Epomaker Magforce 68 is a great option for consumers looking for a compact keyboard option that features a great typing experience. Combined with the Hall Effect technology, the Magforce 68 is suited for many consumers out there. Pros Compact Form Factor High-Quality Gateron Switches Hall Effect Technology Minimal Design Extensive Customization Cons High Pricing Wired Connectivity Buy for from Amazon The links above are affiliate links. As an Amazon Associate, Wccftech.com may earn from qualifying purchases. Deal of the Day Further Reading Time-Sensitive Deal! Discounted Genuine Windows 11 Pro Key for $14.99! Started by six-h , Yesterday, 12:57 PM Please log in to reply 10 replies to this topic #1 six-h six-h Members 450 posts OFFLINE Gender: Male Location: North West England Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Yesterday, 12:57 PM I built an Intel NUC6i5SYH back in 2016 as my daily ride and installed W10. It has (mostly) been all I have needed. Now that 10 support is ending, I was thinking of what I may use next, but really don't want have to go through the Windows installation which I found a nightmare! I am looking at this can anyone offer advice/opinions? The Amazon description seems rather lacking especially in the O.S. area and I wouldn't want to end up with having to buy and install my own copy of Windows! 🙄 Thanks. Back to top BC AdBot (Login to Remove) BleepingComputer.com Register to remove ads #2 Pkshadow Pkshadow Cat Herder Members 16,290 posts OFFLINE Gender: Not Telling Location: On the Brow of the Hill, West Coast, Canada Local time: 11:16 AM Posted Yesterday, 01:15 PM Hi, Not going to wander the site looking for info on what the OS is. No where is it evident. They are wonderful little things and will be a space saver. The question would be What OS, can it be updated, AMD VS Intel chip. There is not enough info. Maybe some answers on their Website here : https://www.bee-link.com/ Edited by Pkshadow, Yesterday, 01:23 PM. " mosquitoes really wake up everyday and choose violence " — dalia (@_dalia7) www.cnn.com/2020/07/23/health/mosquitoes-attraction-humans-future-wellness-scn/index.html Ticks - Lyme disease & anaplasmosis - https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/what-you-should-know-about-the-tick-borne-disease-anaplasmosis-1.6942217 I-7 ASUS ROG Rampage II Extreme / ASUS TUF Gaming F17 / I-7 4770K ASUS ROG Maximus VI Extreme / i-7 14700KF ASUS Prime 790-P WIFI Back to top #3 PhillPower2 PhillPower2 BC Advisor 3,977 posts ONLINE Gender: Male Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Yesterday, 01:17 PM It is okay if you don't do anything graphic intensive, this something that is reflected in the low price. You have had my opinion on it but in all honesty it is secondary to the Amazon reviews provided by purchases of the computer,, anything less than 4.5 out of 5 stars would be off my shopping list tbh. PSU guidance - 10 stripe - Johnny Lucky - PC Mech - PSU Lemon List Which power supply do you need? Due to differing time zones not all of us can always be around at the same time and on occasion there may be a delay between replies. Please note that I do not respond to members who have previously abandoned - not concluded their earlier topics, the assistance here at BC is 100% free, please use this service and not abuse it, knowing the outcome good or bad is valuable information that we all may learn something from. Back to top #4 six-h six-h Topic Starter Members 450 posts OFFLINE Gender: Male Location: North West England Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Yesterday, 01:31 PM @Cat Herder I agree, they are brilliant. I have been an Intel fan for many years but have a sneaky feeling that AMD currently give better bang for the bucks. Since my desire is to gain entry to the W11 party without the graft of installation, the lack of detail on the proffered OS is a deal breaker. Just wondering if there are any Beelink aficionado's here who can clarify just what we would likely receive, seems from the responses on the "hotukdeals site" even the dratted model is also now in dispute!! Back to top #5 six-h six-h Topic Starter Members 450 posts OFFLINE Gender: Male Location: North West England Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Yesterday, 01:34 PM Thanks @PhillPower2, so that's a "No"! Back to top #6 ranchhand_ ranchhand_ Members 5,719 posts OFFLINE Gender: Male Location: Midwest Local time: 12:16 PM Posted Yesterday, 02:09 PM You asked for an evaluation, but have not detailed exactly you want to use this for, so this cripples any responses. The specs are good, and the Ryzen9 CPU is a top-contender. I have built 2 desktops using the Ryzen7 and 32 gigs RAM and they jet through programs on Windows 11. I am about ready to start a new build using the Ryzen7, that's how much I like AMD. If you are going to use it only for streaming videos, watching movies and surfing the internet to shopping sites, etc. the specs are fine. Note what it is intended for with the amount of RAM that is devoted to graphical interface, about half of the 32gigs. So...if you run heavy duty programs such as video editing & creation, this is going to slow down a lot. I am a bit careful because Amazon lists only 15 ratings, and out of those only 5 users actually posted in with reviews. They claim as follows: " 89% positive ratings from 200+ customers " but I don't see those Amazon ratings. They claim this is a gaming machine. I seriously doubt that, unless childrens', low-overhead games that I am sure you would not be interested in are played. They claim this will run Photoshop. Well, ok, maybe only if it comes with Windows11 (not spec'd) and it will run very slow-w-w-w-w. What I don't like is that it appears not to come with an OS, or with one unspecified. Possibly using Linux? That's a deal-breaker for me. Here in the USA Amazon gives a 30-day return period for almost any reason, postage paid. If you have that in the UK then you are pretty safe. Really work the bejabbers out of it immediately to have it prove itself. Honestly, I would pass on it. Edited by ranchhand_, Yesterday, 02:12 PM. If there are no responses to my post for 3 days I remove it from my answer list. If you wish to continue the thread after 3 days please PM me. Back to top #7 six-h six-h Topic Starter Members 450 posts OFFLINE Gender: Male Location: North West England Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Yesterday, 02:48 PM Thanks @ranchhand_ I think my next machine will have an AMD Ryzen cpu but this Amazon offering just gets more vague the more you check it out. You have more or less summed up my intended usage, but I do do quite a lot of Photo manipulation with Elements 2019 and some Video work using Shotcut which my current Intel i5 based NUC manages reasonably quickly though I suspect My demands are few since it achieves all I require with only 8GB of DDR4 ! The total confusion around this Amazon offer leads me to believe that it will not be the specification we think it will be. Returning may also be disappointing since we pay the import duty and tax up front and I suspect that may not be refundable. Think I'll wait for something a little less nebulous! Back to top #8 Pkshadow Pkshadow Cat Herder Members 16,290 posts OFFLINE Gender: Not Telling Location: On the Brow of the Hill, West Coast, Canada Local time: 11:16 AM Posted Yesterday, 10:47 PM Why not email there sales. So the URL in Post #2 https://www.bee-link.com/ well I clicked the Download Link on that URL and got this : Website blocked : https://dr.bee-link.cn v3.0.17 | Riskware: 2.0.202504130205 Malwarebytes Browser Guard blocked this page because it may contain malicious activity. Virustotal result of scan is 1 out of 97 : https://www.virustotal.com/gui/url/7f351b097cddf69084e2c3d67ad5653a8fe23e70b1efb4ce2e60cff5ec5d2b27?nocache=1 For me that would be a deal breaker as know there are others out there as say them several years ago. OS : is Chrome I think. ASUS makes them but not much options on the UK Amazon they are Win11 though. How about this one : https://www.amazon.co.uk/GMKtec-G2-Plus-Desktop-Computer/dp/B0DMS27FJX | UK / EU https://de.gmktec.com/en some powerful stuff. Seems to have a reasonable download site. OS Win 11 and Drivers. Edited by Pkshadow, Yesterday, 10:48 PM. " mosquitoes really wake up everyday and choose violence " — dalia (@_dalia7) www.cnn.com/2020/07/23/health/mosquitoes-attraction-humans-future-wellness-scn/index.html Ticks - Lyme disease & anaplasmosis - https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/what-you-should-know-about-the-tick-borne-disease-anaplasmosis-1.6942217 I-7 ASUS ROG Rampage II Extreme / ASUS TUF Gaming F17 / I-7 4770K ASUS ROG Maximus VI Extreme / i-7 14700KF ASUS Prime 790-P WIFI Back to top #9 PhillPower2 PhillPower2 BC Advisor 3,977 posts ONLINE Gender: Male Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Today, 04:46 AM Thanks @PhillPower2, so that's a "No"! Things that make it a no for me include the below; No upgrade path. The minimal amount of reviews and low scores. Limited twelve month warranty. The computer has basically been cobbled together using unknown technology. The seller's description suggesting that it is a games killer, three year old tech that only has on die video and a notebooks power supply is never going to set the world alight, it may go on fire itself but that's another story. Random example here of from where you can get a better idea of the quality and cost of the type of computer that you are looking for. PSU guidance - 10 stripe - Johnny Lucky - PC Mech - PSU Lemon List Which power supply do you need? Due to differing time zones not all of us can always be around at the same time and on occasion there may be a delay between replies. Please note that I do not respond to members who have previously abandoned - not concluded their earlier topics, the assistance here at BC is 100% free, please use this service and not abuse it, knowing the outcome good or bad is valuable information that we all may learn something from. Back to top #10 six-h six-h Topic Starter Members 450 posts OFFLINE Gender: Male Location: North West England Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Today, 07:15 AM @Pkshadow Odd that Browser Guard has blocked that site, I am running Chrome and also have Browser Guard and AdGuard extensions, yet it has allowed me to view the site! I've had several sites blocked recently by Browser Guard which I've visited many times in the past, so I raised a ticket occasionally and MBAM have usually reported back that they have reviewed their site data and sometimes it seems they're safe. I wasn't aware that you could submit a Site Address to Virus Total for a scan, that's really useful knowledge, thanks! I presume you can also do that with Jotti. I take your point and also the advice of @PhillPower2 and will "step away" from that deal! I think I'll wait and see if there are any good deals during the year. Having always had Intel based machines before, I fancy AMD Ryzen are perhaps better value/faster these days. I've lived with this NUCi5SYH machine with 8GB DDR4 which has been capable of satisfying most of my needs despite having the OS Trashed by Microsoft's engineers who Naused up their attempt to create "Libraries" for me and I ended up with two folders with exactly the same content, ...everything that was on the dratted machine! So traumatised was I from doing the original install, I couldn't face doing it again to correct their mistake. That's why I really need my next machine to have W11 preinstalled. Hopefully something will come along before W10 expires that will fit my fairly conservative needs. Back to top #11 PhillPower2 PhillPower2 BC Advisor 3,977 posts ONLINE Gender: Male Local time: 07:16 PM Posted Today, 07:34 AM Hopefully something will come along before W10 expires that will fit my fairly conservative needs. Golden rule when asking for help with a new rig ( or even upgrading ) is to state your intended use and when possible your maximum budget, if we know your intended use we can do some research for you. Being honest I am a bit taken aback about your almost fear of installing Windows, it is far easier nowadays and especially when you think back to the days when you had to slipstream SATA drivers into Windows XP.
